Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: I glance at the clock as I rinse the dye from my client’s hair, my heart thumping. The online candidate forum for our district is streaming right now, and I promised myself I’d watch, take notes, and finally send in my questions about the new zoning laws. But as I towel-dry her hair, she stares at her reflection, lips pressed tight. “It’s… not quite what I pictured,” she says softly, eyes flicking to the brassy undertones. My training kicks in—I need to listen, reassure her, maybe even redo the colour. That’s my job: to make sure she leaves happy, to fix any mistake, no matter how long it takes. But the forum is live, and I know how important it is to be an active citizen, to speak up for my neighborhood. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, my hands trembling as I reach for the toner, my phone buzzing with forum updates in my pocket. I want to do right by her, and by my community, but I can’t see how to do both at once.
